p5_1: ^, I've got something super cool for you! I've been learning a new programming language for making interactive art called p5.js - The "js" part comes from JavaScript - you've probably heard of that before, it's a programming language used to run lots of websites.
p5_2: ^In this activity, the p5.js code is on the far left, and the result of that code is in the middle. As you type, the code will constantly try to run, and update the middle area.

^It's super important that you type any code exactly as we show it to you! Computers can be very picky about things like spaces! If you make any mistakes, you can always use Undo (Ctrl + Z), or if it's really bad, reset the code completely with the Reload button in the upper right.
p5_3: ^Let's start off with something simple - How about we change that background color. Find the line that says <tt>background(20);</tt>, and change it to read <tt>background('green');</tt>.
^Dont forget the semicolon ( ; ) at the end of the line, and pay attention to your spaces!
p5_4: ^Great job! p5.js understands a lot of different color words - You could also use coral, lime or midnightblue, for example.
p5_5: ^Now, let's go a little deeper and change something about how the wave works! Find the line that says num = 20;, and change 20 to 5. Don't forget to type the code exactly as you see it!
p5_6: ^Huh, where did all our lines go? Try changing num to 15.
p5_7: ^That's a nice number! Next, let's change the space between the arcs. Try changing <tt>step</tt> to 30.
p5_8: ^Hmm, looks like we're going to need a bigger window to contain this wave! We can make the canvas (that's the name of the area the program draws things in) larger by changing the line that says createCanvas(400, 400). Those two numbers control the width and height of your canvas, so let's make that a little bigger - increase the wdith to 600.
p5_10: ^That looks better! You can keep changing the size, if you like.
^Now, let's change the thickness of the arcs. Change strokeWeight from 5 to 10.
p5_11: ^Nice! You can drop the <tt>strokeWeight</tt> back down, or change it to another number you like better.
^Let's move on to some fun with colors - look for the line that says <tt>arcColor = 255</tt>.
^That variable controls the color of all the lines in the wave - let's change it to 100, and see what happens!
p5_14: ^Now your wave is gray! If you want the wave to be blue, green or some other color, we need a more complex way of talking about colors. True, you can use color words, like you did for the background, but you can also describe colors in terms of the amounts of red, green, and blue they have.
^For example, let's make the wave red - change the line with arcColor on it to arcColor = color(255, 0, 0);. Don't forget to double-check your spacing!
p5_16: ^See how the arcs are red? Change the color to <tt>(0, 255, 0);</tt> to give us some lucky green waves.
p5_18: ^Now let’s try blending our RGB values: <tt>color(0, 255, 255);</tt>
p5_19: ^Looks like green and blue make a lovely teal color! Let's try a more complex color - I love the purple you get with <tt>color(150, 0, 255)</tt>
p5_20: ^Great job! Now those are some beautiful waves.
^We're at a crossroads: You can stay here and keep playing around with the colors and what we've learned so far, or... we can forge ahead into something more complicated. How does that sound?

c-1: ^ I'm going to stay here and keep experimenting!

p5_stay: ^Have fun! Remember, you can always restart this quest if you change your mind.

p5_23: ^Great job, and we can also apply the same idea to the background color!
^On the line with <tt>doArcs(...</tt>, add <tt>background(255);</tt> just before for <tt>doArcs(...</tt>
^Your code should now look like this:
p5_24: ^Do you see what we've done here? We used an if statement to change the behavior of this program depending on what you, the user, is doing!
^If you click or touch the canvas, mouseIsPressed is True, so the if statement jumps to the first bit of code, and displays the arcs as your chosen color.
^If you aren't clicking on or touching the canvas, mouseIsPressed is False, so it runs the code inside the else section, and the arcs are the other color.
^You can think of if statements like they're a sentence - If this test is true, do one thing, or else, do a different thing.
p5_25: ^Finally, we’re going to introduce you to another power-user command: the map function. Functions take in some data, and output other data. map takes one set of numbers, and squishes or stretches it to fit another range of numbers. In this case, we're going to use map() to make the position of your mouse control the speed of the wave animation.
p5_26: ^First, let's get familiar with the numbers we'll be changing. Do you see the last line of our code, <tt>theta += 0.0523;</tt>? That number controls the speed of the wave.
^0.0523 is an awfully small number! Let's try increasing it to 0.1. Remember to watch your spaces!
p5_27: ^Wow, that's fast! What happens if we go much smaller than the original, say, <tt>0.001</tt>?
p5_28: ^Very slow! Try to find a happy medium, or you can reset it to <tt>0.0523</tt>.
p5_29: ^Now, let’s use the map function to automate the things we did in the past few instructions. We'll make the vertical position of your cursor control the speed of the wave!
^Change the number after <tt>theta +=</tt> to <tt>map(mouseY, height, 0, 0.001, 0.1);</tt> As usual, be careful to make sure your spaces and the numbers you're typing are correct.
p5_30: ^Check it out! As you move your cursor higher, the wave speeds up. As you move it down, it slows down! And of course, you can still click or touch to change the colors.
p5_31: ^We're done for the moment, but there's so much to explore in p5.js! Feel free to change any of the variables you’ve learned, and play around as much as you like. If you'd like to keep going with more activities like this, I've got a whole set available in Hack for Endless OS!
^You can learn how to use complex shapes, random numbers, programming tools like variables and loops, and even "paint" with sound or create your own games. I'd love to see you there!
